ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I was very pleased with the overall content and readings for the course, although I think changing the syllabus midway caused more help than hurt. I think having the class once per week for longer would be better for maximizing discussion and workshops.

The class is very interesting, but might need some tweaks on planning, to be of best use to students. Syllabus was changed 4 times over the semester, and the final version differ significantly from the original one, which proves that the class is in a constant redesign.

The material covered in this course is fascinating and important, especially for students interested inthe intersection of urban design and ecological systems. Prof. Felson is engaging and passionate; however, the course was disorganized, constantly in flux (i.e. the syllabus changed frequently and the scope of assignments was not explained clearly, making it very hard to plan in advance and engage fully in the projects), and wandering (i.e. the trajectory of the course was never fully clear - we jumped around a lot).

I think it would be better if you made people do an occasional reading response or something on the readings because I think the class would have been better if more students had done the reading. I also think it would have been good to read a few more papers that were from urban ecology experiments - for example taking a class and looking at pollinator studies, or urban to rural gradients etc - but a few classes looking at the real ecology behind the concepts - paired black and white bar graphs every once and a while would be good.
the readings in this class were good but there is a lack of connection betweenthe class readings and our project work.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I really enjoyed the readings and in-class activities.
The course content is extremely interesting and the course has potential to be great, it just is in desperate need of streamlining and better organization.

This is a brand new field, so getting exposure to this exciting, new, interdisciplinary field was incredible. Dr. Felson is an astonishing wealth of knowledge, and it was a privilege to be taught by him. I really enjoyed the field trips, especially to the art museum. I also appreciated Dr. Felson's responsiveness to concerns raised in the middle of the course. His openness to feedback from students is great, and made the course feel like a more iterative process. I have been turned on to a whole new realm of potential engagement through my coursework, and feel that taking this class has very positively impacted by life and education.

The applied work in the Bridgeport case, and final presentation proved to be a very interesting way to link the class discussions (mostly theoretical, and up in the air) back to real case application.
breadthflexibility of course instructor vis-a-vis tackling interdisciplinary challenges
Real world problem solving and consulting-like work.
This was one of the most far-reaching classes I've taken - really challenged assumptions. also the best discussions I've had in any class this year.
The readings and a great opportunity to know RBD better.
Participating in the Rebuild By Design process, applied learning, interdisciplinarity

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Organization was somewhat lacking in terms of when and what was required of students. Weekly clarity as to what readings were required, who would be presenting, and what each class would be dedicated to would have been much appreciated.

There seemed to be a blatant disregard or unawareness for students' time, and class consistently ran over. The class was supposed to end at 11:50, but went until noon regularly. Students were also asked to come in early or stay late on occasion, in order to cover things that we ran out of time on in previous lectures. This would have been okay once or twice, but because this happened so consistently, it felt like an imposition on students whose time is booked down to the minute! Oftentimes there are lectures scheduled for noon, so having class end at 11:50 is imperative in order to get to these lectures/special guest speakers on time (particularly if they are in a different building).Furthermore, we regularly received notification of information about readings and assignments the day before they were expected to be completed, and often at the eleventh hour (literally at 11 p.m. the night before in some cases). This made the entire course feel extremely disorganized, and in fact, the syllabus changed at least half a dozen times. Again, a change or two is to be expected, but the regularity with which this happened was egregious! It made any kind of advance planning or preparation (in terms of personal student scheduling) impossible, and made it difficult to stay motivated or have ample opportunity to really engage with the material (which of course I would have liked to do, but not when I receive the material at midnight the night before a 10:30 a.m. class).This last-minute notification reached its peak when, the day before our final presentations we were informed that a panel of prestigious local individuals was going to be in attendance. Receiving critical feedback from a panel of experts is absolutely valuable, and I have nothing negative to say about that. However, when an assignment has been framed in a certain way to the students(this presentation was intended to be a continuation of a previous assignment, and presented to us as something low-key and not too intensive), and this framing gets changed less than 24 hours before the deliverable is due, it is extremely frustrating and disheartening. Furthermore, the panel clearly had not been briefed on what our assignment was (a 12-minute presentation with very specific parameters). It was again, extremely frustrating when the panelists praised people who did not actually do the assignment as requested (some students' presentations went over much more than 12 minutes, which the panelists loved because it was so thorough) and harshly critiqued those that did because they did not cover certain things. If I had 25 minutes, I would have covered those things!Finally, the actual content of the course just felt a bit all over the place, and is in need of streamlining.

Dr. Felson is brilliant, but not everyone operates on his level. Better organization of the course, with a slightly slower pace, would have been better. Also, he could better outline expectations at the beginning of the term. For example, our experience with Rebuild by Design was great, but we had an "introductory" lecture to the project only after a few months of working on the project. Instead of throwing us into the deep end it would have been nice to have better preparedness/introductions to projects and topics.
Besides organization in the syllabus, assignment feedback will be a valuable plus to the class development
perhaps more direct instruction

It needs to be better organized, respecting students' time and diverse backgrounds - people come to the course with a lot of different experiences and objectives, and the first few weeks should be used to help compensate for gaps and help get everyone up to speed. This might require narrowing the scope of the course, prioritizing depth over breadth.
The syllabus should set in stone in January.
1.) be more clear on the assignment requirement; 2.) be more organized especially for project class; 3.) give more background information for the final project.
Lecture& discussion planning/moderating
More structure to allow students to plan ahead

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The lab, if RBD counts as the lab, was very effective. I think it played a valuable role in engaging the students in the course, although I was somewhat unaware of how quickly intensely the work would ramp up and then decline as a result of the project. Better advertising the engagement with a real-client design competition as well as a middle-semester work heavy schedule could make the class more appealing.
The relationship from the class theoretical framework and the lab sections is what makes the class work. There is a consistent balance in them, and shall be kept forward
N/A
I think it was great to have the first applied project right off the bat - I think it made the whole rest of the readings and theory that much more relevant.
1.) provide more academic references related to RBD; 2.) provide more design/architecture background information.
More time for lecture and discussion-- I think the materials covered in the class are very important for FES. It would be valuable to discuss/debate them with more detail, depth and synthesis.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The class allows to integrate other disciplines into Urbanization issues, and understand how that models design processes. Planning on working in major cities, this is a key feature for my professional skillset
great preparation for interdisciplinary doctoral studies
I'm interested in urban systems, and learning how to integrate the ecological lens into urban design was valuable.
It has definitely changed the direction of what I am hoping to do after FES!
It provides great background on design principles and urban ecology topics.

I am interested in articulating, designing and implementing regional-scale, multifunctional, landscape projects that promote ecological, cultural, social and economic well-being in communities. This class addressed many of the questions I have about that process.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I thought this class was going to be a nice complement to my other courses on the urban built environment and urban design.
I have been craving a course that took science into an actionable realm, and made use of my education thus far.
FES offers few urban courses. This is one of the few courses that link urban systems with ecology - valuable for someone with an interest in urban design.
To learn more about how to apply ecological research principles to urban settings.
To learn how ecological practice and theory apply in urban landscapes, and how they can be used to shape the human understanding and environments.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No.
Yes, and beyond!
Yes
i still have much to learn, but a great introduction
More or less.The articles/literature felt disconnected from the applied portions of the course. I would have liked the theory and practice to be more integrated.
Much more so than I was expecting.
Neutral. The class is more disorganized than I expected but I did learn the practical challenges for environmental consultants and integrating ecological research in urban settings.
This class exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I found the group work to be rewarding and also realistic in terms of the type of professional work the course covered.
The group projects were great, I really enjoyed working with my classmates.

Our class had a diverse set of students and I enjoyed learning from those who had a different educational background and expertise than me. Also, everyone in the class was friendly ad intelligent, and I'm thankful I got to know them.
In tackling interdisciplinary issues as the ones posed in class, group work is key to be representative of real project based work.
for me, it went very smoothly, probably because the professor gave us a great deal of flexibility and we managed time well!

Great to learn from my classmates - everyone brought a unique perspective to our project-based work.Group work can be tough to coordinate, especially when assignments are constantly changing, and popping up with short notice, as was the case during this course.
It's always good to do group work, thought it is inevitably slower and more frustrating than you think. It's always good to do it.
It's great to have someone to brainstorm and work together. My experience is very positive.

Group projects for this class were designed with an interdisciplinary approach, so working in a group with a diverse set of backgrounds and skills was beneficial.However, in some cases, I think it was challenging for students to find a common foundation for the work.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: When the class says it is 10:30-11:50, take that to mean 10:15-12:15. As much as you try to prepare in advance for things, you will be foiled. But, it will keep you on your toes.
Take it! Seriously, take it. But be ready to offer feedback and advice when you want the course to take on a different direction, and be prepared to go on a ride.
It might take a while to understand the class objectives, and how it gets there. Application and examples are a great way to get a rapid idea of how it is framed
keep up with the readings!

Be flexible and open-minded. This material is interesting and Prof. Felson is engaging, but the course is not well organized and may require your own active integration and synthesis to make it worth while.
If you are looking for a traditional class where you can just do readings at night, go to lectures, and turn in papers. It's pretty unconventional and you have to be flexible, but it's worth it!
1.) make sure to check out the projects; 2.) be prepared for some uncertainties; 3.) be ready to work in groups and participate in discussions.
Read all the assigned materials, take the opportunity to be creative
